bibl.title: Letter from Amory H. Hutchinson to Mabel H. Lazear, February 9, 1936

div1.p: Hutchinson reports that her script for the play appears to be rejected. She asks for cooperation in writing a book about Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Amory H. Hutchinson to Mabel H. Lazear, February 9, 1936
div1.p:
I received your
letter on my return from
Nassau where I had
been for a week &
missed its arrival.

I perfectly understand
your feelings about
the play, & I felt
that they should be
respected or I would not
have insisted upon your
being given the opportunity
to choose its fate.

So much of it is necessar-
ily fictitious for the
purposes of stage produc-
tion that it is not the
tribute to Lazear that would
satisfy my own wishes.
And so, while it has
been considered a terribly
moving & appealing &
tightly constructed script,
I am not at all dissatisfied with your
decision. And I am wondering if you
could bring yourself to collaborate with
me in the preparation of a book
which would give scope for accuracy
& historical exactitude.

Absurd as it may seem to you, I so
bitterly feel the injustice of his
effort & distinction passing from recog-
nition, fromthe laymind that I would find an enormous
solace in being able to write what I
am told would be a great book, if you
could consider bringing the facts to
my understanding. On the other hand,
I can again, understand your wishing
never to reopen or reread that
page which must have been so
meshed with joy & bitterness & despair.

The book would be
written I can assure you
in the most profound
respect for all the human
& divine elements which
are the essentials of
the story, & if, as some
believe, I have any
genius for portraying
high deeds & the
varying shades of
human emotion, I
would bring it very
humbly to the task.
I would want especially
to interpret your own
contribution to the pattern
-- for I feel that the destiny
of the man, in almost
every case, is clearer
& more easily rewarded
than in the case of
the woman.

If you feel unequal
to the ordeal please tell
me. At least let me
have the bare facts of the origin of the asso-
ciation & the environment of your own
youth, & your husband's. I would pledge
myself not to use the material until such
time as you specify. I feel that if a
book respecting the facts more closely
than is possible in a play, were written,
your son & daughter would derive no un=
pleasant or harmful reaction from it.

Of course Lazear is an historical
character, & it is inevitable that his
story will be used eventually, if not by
myself, by others. How utterly men
are at the mercy of their biographers
& the historians is always a horror
to me. But I myself can never be the
one to disregard the inalienable per:
sonal rights of individuals. And
that is why you can be assured that nothing
will be done with out your cooperation.
